newsitem.title: USA: Boston Scientific sales jump, stock rises.
newsitem.headline: Boston Scientific sales jump, stock rises.

text.p: Boston Scientific Corp. stock rose sharply Tuesday, a day after the maker of medical devices said net sales for the second quarter jumped 25 percent.

The stock climbed $5.875, or more than 9 percent, to $69.125 on Nasdaq shortly after midday. The stock has gradually recovered ground since dropping to as low as $41 in April after the company warned its first-quarter results would not meet analysts' expectations.
Boston Scientific said Monday its sales rose to $474 million in the quarter ended June 30 from $379 million in the second quarter of 1996, in line with analyst expectations.
The Natick, Mass.-based company said sales would have increased 28 percent if changes in foreign currency exchange rates had not eroded international revenues.
The company said reported revenues include the combined net sales of Boston Scientific Corp. and former rival Target Therapeutics Inc., whose acquisition it completed during the second quarter.
Lehman Brothers analyst Amelia McDonald said Boston Scientific's report gave her "increased confidence" in her second-quarter earnings forecast of 47 cents per share for the company.
According to First Call, analysts on average expect Boston Scientific to report earnings of 44 cents a share in the second quarter, with a range of 40 cents to 47 cents.
The company earned $72.6 million, or 40 cents a share, on revenues of $399.2 million in the first quarter.
A Deutsche Morgan Grenfell analyst upgraded Boston Scientific's stock to buy from accumulate. The analyst was not available for comment.
Boston Scientific said it expects to release complete second-quarter financial results later this month.
